title: Pressure on Donald Trump as US Congress votes to release Epstein files | ABC NEWS
description: After months of delay and fierce opposition from Donald Trump, the US Congress has voted to release the Epstein files. When it finally came to a vote, it wasn't even close. Just one member voted against the bill. As it passed, survivors of Jeffrey Epstein's abuse broke out in applause and cheers. But it's not law yet, with the bill off to the president's desk awaiting his signature. North America correspondent Kamin Gock reports from Washington. title: ASX down slightly after another fall in US stocks overnight | Finance Report | ABC NEWS
description: Australian share markets have closed down after a fairly flat day of trading. The ASX 200 closed down -0.25% to 8,447 points, while the broader All Ordinaries index closed down -0.2% to 8,721 points. Investors are concerned about a possible AI-related slump. Meanwhile, ABS figures show workers received an average base pay increase of 3.4 per cent over the year to September, meaning there could be no more rate cuts in this cycle. title: Why workers could see their real wages go backwards in 2026 | The Business | ABC NEWS
description: Wage growth slightly outpaces consumer price inflation in the year to September, which means the average worker has received a small increase in their purchasing power, a point highlighted by the Treasurer Jim Chalmers.  However, the increase was down on the same period last year and an economist says workers can expect real wages to fall again next year. Wage rises were stronger for workers in the public sector, led by pay rises for employees of state and local governments. The data alleviates any pressure on the Reserve Bank to lower interest rates.  William Buck chief economist Besa Deda thinks there's a possibility of one more cut in the second half of 2026.  The ABS published a second set of monthly numbers, estimating the total wages and salaries paid by employers to their staff in September.  Payments totalled $108.8 billion, driven higher by bonuses in the mining, utilities, retail, media and financial services sectors, which are often paid in September, in response to financial year targets.  However, the 5.3 per cent annual growth in total wages and salaries paid to employees was down from the 6.1 per cent rise recorded over the year to September 2024. #ABCBusiness Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE Read more here: https://www.abc.net.au/news/2025-11-19/abs-wage-price-index-figures-released-september-quarter/106026360  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Cyclone Fina reaches category two strength, expected to cross NT coast on Saturday | ABC NEWS
description: Tropical Cyclone Fina is sitting more than 350 kilometres north-east of Darwin, and has now intensified into a category two.   Fina is tracking north-east away from the Northern Territory, but the weather bureau expects the system to change course and begin moving towards the NT coastline. The storm's path remains uncertain, but forecasters are predicting the system will make landfall at the Cobourg Peninsula, and potentially impact Darwin.  A cyclone watch is currently in place between the Tiwi Islands east to Millingimbi but the watch area will likely be extended.  The weather bureau is warning of destructive wind gusts up to 135 kilometres an hour across the northern coastline as the storm approaches. NT emergency service advises to not panic and have your cyclone kits prepared.   Jack Hislop has this update for ABC News Northern Territory. title: UK toughens asylum policy in overhaul as anti-immigration sentiment rises | The World | ABC NEWS
description: The United Kingdom is set to overhaul its asylum seeker policy in a bid to tackle illegal migration. Home Secretary Shabana Mahmoud revealed the proposed changes, which include making refugee status temporary and narrowing the appeal process in asylum cases. Dr. S Chelvan - the head of immigration, public law and civil liberties at 33 Bedford Row in London - tells The World those who are seeking asylum want safety, not settlement. title: China threatens more countermeasures over Japan PM's Taiwan remarks | The World | ABC NEWS
description: China has threatened "to take further measures" if Japan does not retract a statement about Taiwan. title: US Congress approves release of Epstein files, putting matter before Trump | The World | ABC NEWS
description: A bill to force the release of the Jeffrey Epstein files has passed the US congress after a near-unanimous house vote. The legislation will next go to President Donald Trump, who has indicated he will sign the bill into law after backing down from his fierce opposition to it over the weekend. The Hill's Julia Manchester tells The World it's still unclear if the bill has made its way from the Senate to the White House. title: Bangladesh political tensions spark concerns for garment industry | The World | ABC NEWS
description: Many Bangladesh locals have welcomed the death penalty handed down in absentia to the country's exiled former leader. Sheikh Hasina was found guilty of ordering the killing of hundreds of student protesters last year. But as Loughlin Patrick reports, the political uncertainty since then has taken a toll on some of the country's biggest industries, with concerns the court ruling could flare up tensions.
